author: dwdsquared2
body:
**Events in the US Today (EDT):**

* 8:30am - Core Durable Goods Orders (MoM-Jun) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Durable Goods Orders (MoM-Jun) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 9:00am - The House meets for general session
* 10:30am - Dallas Fed Mfg Business Index (Jul) \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 11:30am - 3&6 Month Bill Auction \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 1:00pm - 2&5 Year Note Auction \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 3:00pm - POTUS participates in a tour of Bioprocess Innovation Center at Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies
   * In Durham, NC
* 3:30pm - POTUS participates in a coronavirus briefing at Bioprocess Innovation Center at Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies
* TBD - Senate Republicans are expected to release their latest coronavirus relief proposal
* Gold jumped to an all-time high and the dollar extended its slump as investors looked ahead to a Federal Reserve decision amid a global smattering of coronavirus outbreaks
* Reminder: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) holds its policy meeting on Tuesday, with an announcement due on Wednesday.
* Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and White House chief of staff Mark Meadows said on Sunday that Congress may need to pass a stopgap bill to maintain enhanced unemployment insurance to Americans.
   * Despite the looming Senate recess, which begins Aug. 7. Pelosi declared on Sunday that “we can’t go home without” an agreement
* Today, a new 14-day self-quarantine order goes into effect in Washington, D.C., for people visiting the city or returning to Washington from most states, with the exception of Maryland and Virginia.
* Hurricane Hanna made landfall as a tropical depression with 50 mph winds, causing flooding in southern parts of Texas.

**Events in the World Today (EDT):**

* 4:00am - Germany Ifo Business Climate Index (Jul) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Germany Bus. Expectations & Curr. Assessment (Jul) \[2/3 Volatility\]
   * Euro Zone M3 Money Supply (YoY-Jun) \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 6:00am - France Jobseekers Total \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 7:25am - Brazil BCB Focus Market Readout \[2/3 Volatility\]
* The U.K.’s decision to impose a two-week quarantine on travelers returning from Spain has put a chill on European stock markets Monday, puncturing assumptions that Europe would avoid a second wave of the coronavirus and casting doubt over their ability to outperform U.S. stocks for once.
* China reported the greatest number of domestic cases since mid-March. Hong Kong imposed new restrictions as a renewed outbreak showed no sign of abating. Hong Kong will ban all dine-in services at restaurants, require masks outdoors and limit public gatherings to two people.

**Earnings Before Open:**

* Hasbro, SAP, RPM, Ameris Bancorp, Bank of Hawaii, Albertsons Corp., Community Bank System, Lincoln Electric, Alliance Resource

**Earnings After Close:**

* NXP, f5 Networks, Amkor Tech, Brown & Brown, AGNC, Hexcel, TCF, Crane, Cincinnati Financial Corp, Alexandria

[Earnings This Week](https://i.redd.it/6i19e9do82d51.jpg)

author: TheSweetestKill
body:
First off, save your F5 key, keep this website open in a tab. I listen to it all during trading hours. https://wsbsynth.com/

Second, same here with the job. What sort of intel do you look for? Since covid I have been working from home and I basically have fuck all to do most days, so I've been spending a lot of time researching and watching wsb and trading options. But I can't seem to find a decent strategy to win OR lose, it seems like I wind up week after week +10% or -10% but nothing crazy in either direction. My portfolio all time is only +5.3%.

author: nostrautist
body: I love all the people grasping at bullshit to explain minute-by-minute moves.  Find the trend.  Buy far enough out so you have some time.  Profit.  Stop being a desperate F5 hoe.

author: aditenz716
body:
It's the busiest week of second-quarter earnings season, with 171 S&P 500 companies scheduled to report.  

 Monday 7/27

F5 Networks , Hasbro , and SAP report quarterly results.

The Census Bureau releases the Durable Goods report for June. Expectations are for a 5.5% rise in new orders for durable manufactured goods, to $205 billion, after a 15.7% jump in May.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas reports its Texas Manufacturing Outlook survey for July. Economists forecast a reading of just above zero, continuing the index's rebound from records lows in March and April.

Tuesday 7/28

3M , Advanced Micro Devices , Altria Group , Amgen , eBay , McDonald's , MSCI , Mondelez International , Pfizer , Raytheon Technologies , S&P Global , Starbucks , and Visa report earnings.

The Conference Board releases its Consumer Confidence Index for June. Consensus estimate is for a 95.5 reading, slightly below May's 98.1.

Wednesday 7/29

The Federal Open Market Committee announces its monetary policy decision. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates near zero through 2022.

Boeing , Crown Castle International , Facebook , General Electric , Norfolk Southern , PayPal Holdings , Qualcomm , Sanofi , and Shopify report quarterly results.

The National Association of Realtors releases its Pending Home Sales Index for June. The index is seen rising 5.4% to a 105 reading, after a record spike of 44.3% in May.

Thursday 7/30

Alphabet , Amazon.com , American Tower , Apple , Comcast , ConocoPhillips , Electronic Arts , Eli Lilly , Ford Motor , Gilead Sciences , Moody's , Newmont , Northrop Grumman , Procter & Gamble , and United Parcel Service hold conference calls to discuss earnings.

The Bureau of Economic Analysis reports gross domestic product for the second quarter. Consensus estimate is for a decline of 34%, after a 5% fall in the first quarter. The largest quarterly drop recorded was 10% for the first three months of 1958. The BEA's release will probably confirm the end of the longest economic expansion in U.S. history, which began in June of 2009.

Friday 7/31

AbbVie , Caterpillar , Charter Communications , Chevron , Colgate-Palmolive , Exxon Mobil , Merck , Phillips 66 , and Under Armour report earnings.

The Institute for Supply Management releases its Chicago Purchasing Manager Index for July. Economists forecast a 42 reading, above June's 36.6 but still below the expansionary level of 50, which the index hasn't surpassed since last summer.

The BEA reports personal income and spending for June. Expectations for a 3% decline in income and a 6% jump in spending. This compares with a 4.2% drop and a 8.2% gain, respectively, in May.

&#x200B;

\-Barrons

author: lucidvein
body:
Not too shabby OP.  I have all of those except Coca Cola, Pepsi, and McDonalds since most of their stuff is based on unhealthy products even w/ their market penetration I'm not convinced society is heading in that direction.

I can post my top 20 holdings for you.  I've been lucky enough to typically beat the S&P.  40% of my portfolio are in mutual funds but my individual picks are:

1. Amazon: 6.6% - #1 Ecommerce subscription \[moat\], hardware, twitch, ecosystem
2. Johnson and Johnson: 6% - #1 Pharma giant
3. Next Era Energy: 5.8% - Moated energy utility in SE USA, going 20% solar too soon
4. Google: 5.0% - #1 Search engine, Data monster, Youtube, Invests in SpaceX etc.
5. Gold: 5% - Hedge
6. Intel: 4.6% - Chipset King.  Might dip w/ AMD on rise.
7. Cadence Design: 4% - Electronic Design Automation
8. Apple: 3.7% - World class phone maker, ecosystem, cult following w/ services
9. Microsoft: 3.4% - Azure, Office Suite, Windows, Solid
10. Lockheed Martin: 3.4% - Defense spending won't be going away. Industry leader.
11. Illumina: 3% - Genetic Analysis, human health advancement
12. Wheaton Precious Metals: 2.8% - Favorite precious metals miner
13. United Health Group: 2.8% - Industry leader in Health Insurance
14. Waste Management: 2.6% - Garbage isn't going to go away anytime soon
15. Market Axcess: 2.5% -  Electronic trading platform for bonds/fixed income
16. Disney: 2.3% - Media & entertainment giant
17. Nvidia 1.8% - #1 video card company, gaming, business visualization, solid AI r&d
18. Raytheon: 1.5% - More Defense
19. Visa: 1.4% - Fintech & market penetration
20. Adobe: 1.4% - Subscription service for top graphic suite
21. Crispr: 1.1% - Genetic Editing R&D and interesting possibilities

Some other stocks I own and don't mind recommending are HD, LULU, BLK, SPCE (can't fight the memes), Alibaba, Tencent, Qdel, Fortinet, Berkshire, Paypal, Texas Instruments, Qcom, some beat down covid stocks like RCL & Boeing.

author: NocNocNoc19
body: Im not sure how much money you have to start with. Vanguard index funds have been my overall best investment. Voo, VTI, VT. if you dont have enough to buy whole shares of those robin hood offers fractional shares but I have never gone that route so I honestly don't know how good of a thing they are. Other then that do a lot of research. Read a lot. Dont buy and think your going to sell again any time soon. Ive only been actually investing for about 2 years. In that time I have only sold 1 position because I no longer liked the investment long term. Everything else i have bought with the intent to hold for 10+ years baring something extremely unforeseen. I buy a lot of blue chips and companies im somewhat familiar with as well. I work in tech so I own cisco, palo alto, fortinet, netapp because I work with there products a lot. But i probably only own about 30 individual companies and over 50% of my portfolio is in those index funds i mentioned earlier. Is this winning advice, I have no idea but its been working for me.

author: lupi5
body:
I’m 24. Started 2 years ago and made a new strategy for myself, started this buying around June and have added a couple. 

ROKU - 105 (~20%). Sell 240

author: shacoand2boxes
body:
Akamai Technologies stock is trading higher Thursday after Cowen analyst Colby Synesael raised his rating on the content-delivery network company to Outperform from Market Perform, while upping his target price to $150 from $107.

Synesael is basically making the observation (which I made in an April Tech Trader column) that Akamai shares (ticker: AKAM) have not participated in the huge rally in internet infrastructure plays amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The analyst says there is now a "meaningful disconnect" between Akamai and other security and CDN stocks, despite its larger scale, higher profitability and " still solid growth." He sees Akamai as an "attractive way" to play long-term trends like cloud security and edge computing.

Synesael points out that the stock looks cheap relative to both security plays like Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Fortinet (FTNT) and to other content- delivery networks, such as Cloudflare (NET), Fastly (FSLY), and Limelight Networks (LLNW). He argues that Covid-19 has served as a catalyst to Akamai's security and CDN businesses.

"We believe Covid-19 has resulted in increased demand for both its enterprise and internet security product offerings given the increase in the number of attacks across organizations and the internet," Synesael writes. "We believe Akamai's security business is an underappreciated component of its long- term growth opportunity and that as it becomes a larger portion of total revenue more investors are likely to start valuing it on its [sum of the parts] which we believe will result in a significant re-rating of the stock."

The analyst notes that there have been investor concerns about the company losing market share to peers like Fastly, but asserts that "the growth of competitors is more a function of an expanding opportunity for CDN providers rather than share stealing from Akamai."

Akamai shares were up 7%, at $113.78, in recent trading, while the S&P 500 was up 0.9%. The stock is up about 32% year to date, which is impressive growth -- except when compared with Cloudflare, which has more than doubled, and Fastly, which has more than quadrupled

author: TheTigersAreNotReal
body:
GLW: Glass manufacturer that is used in vials, phones, TVs, and other medical/commercial appliances. They have a contract to produce vials for Pfizer, and received a grant from the government to ensure that they will be able to produce enough vials for the future vaccine. Had their price target upgraded to $33 by Citigroup, currently oversold at $25.75

Don’t know when this thing is gonna moon again, but I hope it’s soon. Probably needs to announce another biomed contract to turn more heads. White knuckling these calls hoping the market realizes its value soon

author: math1024
body:
The main difference between 5G and the previous roll outs is just a lot more fiber and small cell antennas. I think the best 5G plays would be fiber companies like GLW, COMM, and OCC.

There's also been [legislation](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_13858) promoting onshoring so you might want to focus on american manufacturers.
